intro: Uropappus lindleyi var. clevelandii, commonly known as Cleveland's jointfir, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and fibrous root system. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations such as silver foliage and reduced leaf size to minimize water loss. Its small, yellow to orange flowers appear in clusters, contributing to its ornamental value in dry landscapes. The variety is distinguished by its specific geographic distribution and morphological traits compared to other Uropappus species.
